items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this afternoon, Saturday 08/01/22. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 3.0 to 3.5m Saturday afternoon, 08/01/22; Cae Howel 3.9 to 4.3m Sunday morning, 09/01/22.   
Further showers are forecast over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 5pm on 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Please note there is potential for levels to rise again tomorrow afternoon, Sunday 9th January. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible from 5am on Saturday.

Heavy rain is forecast across Mid and East Devon over Friday night into Saturday morning. This is expected to cause river levels in the River Clyst and Culm catchments to rise.

We expect flooding to affect  Cullompton, Willand, Culmstock, Hemyock, Bradninch, Broadclyst, Clyst St Mary.
Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. 
 
River levels will remain high throughout the weekend as further heavy showers are forecast, please take care near the areas of concern.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

This message will be updated as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 08/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Further persistent rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to begin rising around 01:00 on 08/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and closing flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Saturday, 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning, 08/01/22. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to begin rising during this morning on 08/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are stable on the Bristol Avon at Bradford-on-Avon and on the Semington Brook at Semington.  Levels are expected to rise today due to this morning's rain but no Flood Warnings are currently forecast for this area.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
Rain will ease through Saturday and only small amounts are forecast going in to next week.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels have risen in the early hours of this morning Saturday 08/01/22 on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck due to heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near these watercourses, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. Flooding is possible this morning with some further rainfall over the next few hours. Following this band of rain there should be drier interludes with just showers to follow today and for Sunday and Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation but we are not expecting any further flooding impacts. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, Sunday 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Caen, Bradiford Water, River Yeo

items.message:

Heavy rain is forecast across North Devon over Friday night into Saturday morning. This is expected to cause river levels in North Devon to rise.

We expect flooding to affect  Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin.
Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. 
 
River levels will remain high throughout the weekend as further heavy showers are forecast, please take care near the areas of concern.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation .
